title: HMS A12
text:
HMS "A12" was an <a href="submarine">submarine</a> built for the <a href="Royal%20Navy">Royal Navy</a> in the first decade of the 20th century. After surviving World War I, she was sold for <a href="ship%20breaking">scrap</a> in 1920.
Design and description.
"A12" was a member of the <a href="A-class%20submarine%20%281903%29">first British class of submarines</a>, although slightly larger, faster and more heavily armed than the <a href="lead%20ship">lead ship</a>, . The submarine had a length of <a href="length%20overall">overall</a>, a <a href="beam%20%28nautical%29">beam</a> of and a mean <a href="draft%20%28ship%29">draft</a> of . They <a href="displacement%20%28ship%29">displaced</a> on the surface and submerged. The A-class submarines had a crew of 2 officers and 9 <a href="naval%20rating">ratings</a>.
For surface running, the boats were powered by a single 16-cylinder <a href="Wolseley%20Motors">Wolseley</a> <a href="petrol%20engine">petrol engine</a> that drove one <a href="propeller%20shaft">propeller shaft</a>. When submerged the propeller was driven by a <a href="electric%20motor">electric motor</a>. They could reach on the surface and underwater. On the surface, "A12" had a range of at ; submerged the boat had a range of at .
The boats were armed with two <a href="British%2018%20inch%20torpedo">18-inch (45 cm)</a> <a href="torpedo%20tube">torpedo tube</a>s in the bow. They could carry a pair of reload torpedoes, but generally did not as they would have to remove an equal weight of fuel in compensation.
Construction and career.
"A12" was ordered as part of the 1903–04 Naval Programme from at <a href="Vickers">Vickers</a>. She was laid down at the <a href="shipyard">shipyard</a> in <a href="Barrow-in-Furness">Barrow-in-Furness</a> in 1903, <a href="Ship%20naming%20and%20launching">launched</a> on 3 March 1905 and completed on 23 September.
